title: boy could wait years treatment
story: Boy could wait years for treatment so he can walk because hes too ticklishConor Stapleton suffers from tight tendons which mean his feet point nearly perpendicular to the ground meaning he struggles to walk or stand up properlyJade Hatton and her -month-old Conor Stapleton Image: MEN MediaByHelena VestyKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A young boy might be forced to “wait years” for treatment that will let him walk again because “he’s too ticklish”. Conor Stapleton has the bizarre condition where his feet point almost perpendicular to the ground all the time.This leaves the -month-old unable to walk properly.Worried mum Jade Hatton first spotted the issue when Conor was around -weeks-old, Manchester Evening News reported.She said that she was told by health visitors to monitor his mobility on two occasions, but in the nearly two years since she claims his situation has only grown more dire and left him unable to walk or even put on shoes. Jade, from Hyde in Greater Manchester, said: “[Doctors] checked him when he was born, but didn’t say anything. But when he was -weeks-old, I could tell there was something wrong with his feet.  “I said to the health visitor that his feet were pointed, the visitor said he was fine. “When he got to about nine months, they were questioning me why he wasn’t trying to walk, or stand against things to bend down and pick things up. “I said it was because of his feet. They said ‘wait until he’s one’, then ‘wait until he’s  months’. Growing ever more worried, the -year-old mum took her son to the GP. They confirmed Conor was suffering from tight tendons, meaning he can only perch on his toes for a brief amount of time.  After already being referred to one hospital, the mum says she then had to aposwait months for an appointmentapos to see a specialist at a second hospital. She added: “Then in June last year, I went to the doctor again who said it was tight tendons, it took them ages to get me an appointment. “I went to Tameside Hospital, where the doctor said it was tight tendons, I then had to wait two, three months for an appointment at the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital. When Jade and Conor finally reached the doctor who would be putting casts on his feet in order to begin to correct his standing, the family were told he was apostoo ticklishapos, claims Jade. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Now, she says she has been referred back to Tameside, leaving her confused. Jade continued: “I went on January , took him in. The [doctor] sat down, she felt his feet and said ‘he’s too ticklish - to make my job easier, I’m not going to put his cast on today, I’m going to wait until he’s older and know why he’s having it done’. “Those were the doctor’s actual words. That appointment was specically for him to have his casts on because he can’t wear shoes, it’s a struggle putting his socks on. He can’t do anything at all. Not only are Conoraposs pointed feet giving him trouble learning to walk, there are other huge development impacts, adds the mum. “It’s made him extremely clingy to me, said Jade. Even when I take him to playgroups, he won’t go over to other children, and they won’t come over to him because he’s crawling. “So he can’t interact or play with them. “When he’s standing against the couch, he’s flopping back down and hurting his leg or banging his head. He’s learned to walk on his knees, and they’re getting bruised. “He just stays at home most of the time, playing with his cars or reading his books because that’s all he can do. “I wanted to take him to nursery, but he won’t be able to do things children his age do because they go out at playtime or go for walks in the woods. He would have to be in a pram. “And he’s getting that stressed and upset now because he can’t get about, he’s starting to have bad mood swings. “If he wants to climb on something and I don’t have the time to pick him up straight away, he’ll scream because he can’t get up on his own yet because of his feet.A complaint has been lodged with the NHS apos Patient Advice and Liaison Serviceby the mum, but she says she fears it could be aposyearsapos before Conor gets his casts - as delays to treatments across the health system continue in the wake of the pandemic. “I feel like screaming because I’ve been saying this since he was -weeks-old. I think people feel like it’s not a big deal because he’s not theirs, they don’t have to deal with him getting stressed and upset. “I rang PALS to complain and they came back to me saying they wanted a doctor to go over his feet again for the third time, she says. “The PALS staff member told me thatI didn’t hear back in a week, to let them know. It’s been about two-and-a-half weeks and I’ve heard nothing back. “It just feels like I’m not being listened to. He really needs casts to help him because his feet are so pointed. “My friend’s kids, who are even younger than him, who are walking, he can’t do anything like that. It puts a knot in my chest because he can’t walk, he can’t play. “I’ve been trying my hardest since he was -weeks-old and I don’t know what to do anymore, I’m stuck.  Adding to her anxiety, Jade is pregnant again and cannot continue to pick Conor up to carry him around like she used to. “I’m also  weeks pregnant, says Jade. I can’t keep carrying him aroundhe needs to go somewhere, itaposs putting pressure on my stomach and back lting him up. Iaposve had miscarriages in the past. But he canapost have a regular bed, he needs a cot that I have to lt him out of, because he could roll out and not be able to get back up. My partner works nights so itaposs usually me there. Heaposs like a baby thataposs as heavy as a toddler. I feel like Iaposm on my own. A spokesperson for Manchester University Foundation Trust, which runs the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital, said: “Conor’s mother has been in touch with our Patient Advice and Liaison Service and they’ll be discussing his referrals and treatment with her directly.” Tameside and Glossop Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust Fountain declined to comment. title: brits rather live with covid
story: Millions of Brits are happy to live with Covid and continue wearing masks in publicNearly three-quarters are fed up with the constantly-changing rules and restrictions, and are ready to accept the virus as part of everyday leFour in ten Brits are happy to continue wearing face masks in public places Image: Wiktor Szymanowicz Future Publishing Getty ImagesByMartin Winter:,  Jan |commentsMillions of Brits are happy to live with Covid and are prepared to continue wearing masks in public – whilst also coming to terms with the increased complications of booking holidays. As the government relaxes “Plan B” restrictions in preparation to simply “live” with Covid rather than introduce more lockdowns, a study of , adults found  percent agree this is the best way forward. More than halfare happy “living with Covid”, with the average adult feeling this way for the last five months – despite soaring numbers over the winter, and the introduction of more restrictions in December. While more than seven in ten are “fed up” with the ever-changing rules and regulations, and would rather accept the virus as part of everyday le instead. And  percent are okay with the fact they might have to always wear masks in public places, while  percent no longer careit means booking holidays are now “complicated” and “uncertain”. Despite this, almost a quarterwould oppose the ideathe government confirmed this decision. A spokesman for lateral flow test provider, RapidTests, which commissioned the survey, said: “Itaposs understandable people have had enough of how weaposve been living for the past two years, and are keen to get back to “normal”.“Our research has shown how adults are prepared to accept Covid as part of their daily lives. “People are keen to enjoy making plans without the fear of last-minute cancellations and wasted money.” Workplaces, international and domestic travel, and live events are among the places people would most like to see restrictions come to an end – with nightclubs at the bottom of the list. Of those who are still working from home,  percent miss their usual place of work to some degree. And it’s reached such a point that half of those polled don’t remember a time before the pandemic, where mask-wearing or travel restrictions weren’t the norm. Nearly six in ten have even stopped booking holidays altogether, because it’s too stressful when worrying about delays or cancellations. And  percent have already experienced trips that have had to be postponed or changed. The research, conducted via OnePoll, also revealed just how many don’t feel Covid is as much of a threat – with more than a third of those who are fully vaccinated believing themselves to be “pretty much immune” to any serious symptoms of the virus. In fact, of those who know they have caught Covid at one stage or another, more than half said their symptoms were better than expected.The spokesman for RapidTests added: “It’s such a hard call to make as the vaccine has had a major impact on cases, but coronavirus does not seem to be going anywhere anytime soon.“It’s great that we have tests available to monitor the virus in hope that we can try and live as normal le as possible going forward.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusFace MasksCoronavirus vaccine" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

title: dragons den reject secures double
story: Dragons Den reject secures double investment after being turned downA Dragons Den candidate has told how he bounced back from rejection after his appearance promoting his non-alcoholic beer on the hit BBC show didnt go as plannedDragons Den reject Mark Wong says it was a great learning experience Image: Mark WongByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Jan |commentsDragonaposs Den has helped launch some incredible businesses in recent years - but the show has also missed out on a few opportunities. One candidate who appeared on the hit BBC show last night has told how heaposs bounced back after being rejected. Entrepreneur Mark Wong pitched his non-alcoholic beer to Sara Davies, Peter Jones, Deborah Meaden and Touker Suleyman and new Dragon Steven Bartlett.He moved to the UK from Hong Kong as a teenager unable to speak English but went on to study philosophy at Durham University. He was forced to give up a career as a wine expert after being diagnosed with alcohol-induced liver damage - prompting him to look at the non-alcoholic options. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here He developed Imbossibrew - a beer brewed with plants to help you unwind without the alcohol and was invited to pitch it to the Dragons after winning several awards. But none of the Dragons was interested, commenting that he was too early into his business journey’ and ‘There was too much competition in the industry. But since walking out of the Den empty-handed Mark has secured almost double the investment and the company has grown by % and won a gold award at the European Beer Challenge beating. Mark said: It was a great learning opportunity. I never thought I’d be on Dragon’s Den, let alone being invited to pitch - for that I’m extremely grateful. The comments from the Dragons were very constructive and I didn’t regret a single moment in the Den. We’ve only just begun the journey to change the way we drink - and I can’t wait to show them our progress in - years.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BBCDurham UniversityDragons DenAlcohol" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: fugitive dubbed uks version hot
story: Fugitive dubbed UKs version of hot felon Jeremy Meeks following police appealSmitten admirers made over , comments as police in Yorkshire try to track down Jonathan Cahill, , but not many of the remarks were going to aid the re-capture of CahillOne saidthey find Jonathan Cahill, hell be begging the police to take him Image: West Yorkshire PoliceByAshley PembertonSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan  A fugitive has been hailed as the UKaposs answer to aposhot felonapos Jeremy Meeks after admirers hijacked a search appeal saying they were looking for him too.Police are trying to track down Jonathan Cahill,  - urgently wanted on prison recall.They went public with a mug shot, telling people to keep a look out for the crook who is due back inside and it quickly attracted , comments. However, none of them were too helpful with most responses coming from smitten women saying they also want to find him as they vowed to join the hunt. Cahill was released from prison last September after serving part of a sentence for burglary.  West Yorkshire Police believe he has breached the terms of his release and has now been recalled to prison.The reaction led to comparisons to American fugitive Jeremy Meeks, who was dubbed aposthe worldaposs hottest felonapos and landed a modelling contract on his release from prison. He was arrested for possessing a gun and jailed for  months in February  after admitting the charge. Brits have reacted the same way and many clearly want to catch him before police do. One response read: I hope heaposs not out in the cold. I have a spare roomhe wants Oh and a pair of handcuffs. Another teased cops: : Leave it with me, Iaposll find him. A third wrote: If I find him heaposll be begging the police to take him! -year-old in a powerchair last seen on m chasing wanted fellon! The comments kept on coming. Another put: Christ almighty. he can hide under my bed while one loved-up lady joked: Heaposll be asking for police protection soon enough when he sees this. A spokesman for West Yorkshire Police said: Officers are continuing enquiries to locate Cahill, who is described as being of medium build and approximately six feet tall. He is believed to be currently residing in Wakefield. title: inside barnard castle as tourism
story: Inside Barnard Castle – as tourism numbers soar after Dominic Cummings lockdown rowDespite standing proud since the th century, Barnard Castles attraction to sightseers up and down the country has reached an all-new high - heres everything you need to know about Dom Cummings favourite destinationBarnard Castle has been given a boost by Dominic Cummings Image: Getty ImagesByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Jan |comments The people of the sleepy Durham market town of Barnard Castle have a lot to be thankful for when it comes to Dominic Cummings, the Prime Ministeraposs former aide who put their little town on the list of aposmust seeapos British Heritage sites.Now firmly aposon the mapapos, Barnard Castle is enjoying some of its finest days since the Balliol family were successfully able to fight off Lord Eustace de Vescy at the siege of . Such fine days, in fact, that English Heritage reports tourism numbers to the historic site were up a whopping % on  levels, as more than , tourists flocked to the beauty spot - an invasion six times larger than the infamous siege of .Despite adult tickets being available for as little as £., not everyone has enough time to squeeze in a trip to the castle following their visit to one of the townaposs two opticians. If you are sadly one of these people then fear not, because weaposve wrapped up some of the must-know information for visitors to the -year-old site, with the help of English Heritage.Barnard Castle history  The first stones are thought to have been put down on the site in  after the Norman Conquest of England. They were laid above the river Tees with the hope of controlling river crossings between the territories of two landowners. It is thought to have been built by the Picard knight Guy de Balliol who was succeeded by his son Berndard, who gave the castle its name. After his death in the mid-th century, the castle underwent ious improvements and developments until it was laid siege to in  by northern forces loyal to King Alexander II of Scotland. The siege was bloody but the defending Balliol family held off their advances, and the castle and those who lived in it entered into a period of prosperity.  From the early th century until the late th, the castle changed ownership multiple times with the comings and goings of ious lords, eventually falling into the hands of King Richard III. The king liked the castle and performed several repairs. He installed the still stunning projecting oriel window of the great chamber that overlooks the river and took great care of it until his death at the Battle of Bosworth in . The castle fell into the hands of the ruling Tudor family until the siege of , which saw , northern rebels attack Barnard Castleaposs -strong army. After a heroic fight, the forces of the castleaposs keeper, Sir George Bowes, were beaten into submission and the castle fell into ruin. After a brief stint being occupied by a chap known as Frank Shields the hermit, the castle slowly morphed into the gorgeous heritage site and example of medieval architecture you can see today. What do visitors say about Barnard Castle  Barnard Castle is a hit with TripAdvisor reviewers, with the ancient ruin laying claim to a very honourable . stars on the site after  reviews.User dawmouse said in December : We went to Barnard Castle on a recent trip to Durham just to see what the fuss was about! Its a very nice little town with lovely local shops  well worth a visit for an afternoon strolling around  shopping. Another, TeamWard, said: Barnard Castleaposs Castle is well worth a visit, the place would have looked mighty impressive + years ago with the sheer size of the area it covers, some excellent views of the river tees, plenty of ruins to explore and well supported by English Heritage and not Mr D M Cummings.  A third, called Steve-and-Andie, said: You donapost need your eyes tested to how lovely and peaceful this ruined castle is. Well maintained th century ruined castle with loads of information boards. Good views over the river Tees. Parking is a bit of a pain in town. Give yourself a good hour for your visit. Not everyone was so impressed though. User RchardN, said: We wanted to include Barnard Castle in our sight seeing tour. The signage for the castle is almost non existent until you are on top of it. Then there was just a very small sign no bigger than a street sign. To add to our frustration the doors were shut and it was closed. I checked the English Heritage website but there was no mention of closure. When is the best time to go to Barnard Castle  English Heritage says many of its sites can get particularly busy on bank holidays and between am and pm. Instead it suggests visiting outside of these hours for a quieter trip. For the best time to visit with virtually no one  there, you might want to consider going in the middle of a national lockdown. news uk-news inside-prince-andrews-bond-prince-"Prince Charles ignores question about Prince AndrewByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Senior royals are said to be “deeply shocked” by Prince Andrew’s decision to demand a trial by jury over sexual abuse allegations against him. And it is thought that Andrew’s older brother Prince Charles is among those concerned by the latest twist in his legal battle.The heir to the throne reportedly also played a major part in the decision to strip the Duke of York of his military titles and royal patronages earlier this month. Despite being brothers, the pair had very dferent upbringings and have also had very dferent adult lives. And it appears there have been several incidents - partly driven by Charles’ desire for a slimmed-down Monarchy - that have proved there has been tension between them… Dferent childhoods Charles is the eldest son of the Queen and the late Prince Philip with his birth coming in .Andrew was born in  - meaning there is an age gap of  years, so the pair didn’t really grow up together. But despite having the same parents, it seems that Charles and Andrew had very dferent experiences growing up.Experts believe the Queen has long felt the weight of raising Charles to be the next king - but with Andrew, she is said to have a far more hands-on relationship. Royal author Katie Nicholl told the documentary: There is a real tension between Charles and Andrew. Andrew has a very dferent relationship with his mother and the Queen was much more hands-on. Princess Dianaaposs former butler Paul Burrell added: Andrew has always been the Queenaposs favourite son and he has never done anything wrong in her eyes. While journalist Penny Junor said: I think the Queen has always had a bit of a blind spot when it comes to Prince Andrew. Close wives Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.In the s, both Princes were granted grand weddings when they wed their respective ex-wives - Princess Diana and Sarah Ferguson. Diana and Sarah had a close bond and they were often pictured chatting at events, such as Ascot.They even took their children on skiing holidays together with Fergie frequently describing Diana as her best friend. This meant Charles and Andrew also spent a lot of time together, with royal expert Katie Nicholl noting the brothers had more companionship between them at that stage in their le than perhaps at any other. However, neither marriage lasted and both were orced by . Slimmed-down monarchy  As heir to the throne, Charles has spent his entire le preparing for the day he takes to the throne to become King.And it’s long been reported that he plans for a slimmed-down monarchy with a team of seven senior royals - that doesn’t include Prince Andrew or his daughters Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie.This came to a head in , when Beatrice and Eugenie were stripped of their -hour taxpayer-funded security.And one royal expert said Charles was forced to intervene in the debate about funding for Beatrice and Eugenieaposs security after it caused a row behind palace walls.It is thought the heir to the throne stepped in after the younger of his nieces racked up huge security costs as she travelled the world on her gap year. A report published at the time suggested Eugenie spent more than £, of taxpayersapos money as she explored India, America, Thailand and South Africa. Charles reportedly stepped in to control the spending, with royal author Angela Levin telling the programme Beatrice and Eugenie: Pampered Princesses  he suggested the sisters didnapost need costly security as itaposs unlikely they will ever become working royals.  But Charlesaposs suggestion didnapost go down well and is said to have left Andrew furious. Meanwhile another incident between the brothers also reportedly left Andrew angry. It came in  when the Queen was celebrating her Diamond Jubilee and an appearance by the royals on the Buckingham Palace balcony was planned.It was reported that Charles had a hand in the decision for only senior royals, such as the Duchess of Cornwall, Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, to appear on the balcony - leaving Andrew dismayed. Royal expert Richard Kay wrote in the Daily Mail in : For Andrew, according to one close figure, being excluded from the balcony scene was a sudden and totally unexpected demotion from front-rank to peripheral royal. It was ‘like a dagger to his heart and he hasn’t got over it’.But this was a dramatic statement of intent by Charles, who long ago decided that when he is king the Royal Family would be ‘slimmed down’. But as a friend of the Duke of York says: ‘The speed and suddenness with which Charles has acted has taken Andrew’s breath away. It’s dreadfully high-handed.’ Public duties In , Andrew gave a famous car crash interview with BBC Newsnight and spoke atabout his association with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.Andrew vehemently denied any accusations of wrongdoing over his links to Epstein, including allegations he had sex with Virginia Giuffre when she was  years old. In the days after the interview, his le began to change considerably and he stepped down from public duties. After the sad death of his father Prince Philip, Andrew talked to television crews outside All Saints Chapel, Windsor Lodge, to express the feelings of the Royal Family. He also very briefly appeared in a documentary about his fatheraposs le in September.However, it was reported in October that royal sources had claimed his siblings have ruled out anyback to public le for Andrew.An insider told the Sunday Times that a meeting was held last January where Charles - along with Princess Anne and Prince Edward were in agreement that their brother should never be allowed toto public le.Stripping titles  Last year, Virginia Giuffre began the process of suing Andrew in a civil case in New York for allegedly sexually assaulting her when she was a teenager.And earlier this month, a judge decided the Queenaposs son will have to face a civil trial. Andrew vehemently denies all allegations.Buckingham Palace then announced that Andrew would not undertake any public duties and that his military associations and royal patronages have been ed to the Queen. Charles is said to have had a hand in the decision to remove Andrew’s titles - along with his younger son William.And royal expert Robert Jobson said they had no other choice. He told the Mirror: “Prince Andrew will be devastated at the way he has been cut adrt by the royal family. But the Queen, Prince Charles and Prince William - the main players in this shocking move - will feel they had no choice.” After Buckingham Palaceaposs announcement, a reporter asked Charles a question about Andrew, but he didnapost answer. Proceeding to trialThe latest news in Andrew’s legal battle came earlier this week when his legal team filed documents in New York stating he “hereby demands a trial by jury on all causes of action asserted in the complaintHe also officially denied to the court a catalogue of sex abuse allegations brought by his accuser.  And now it’s been reported that Charles, as well as William, are aposshockedapos Andrew wants to fight his civil sex abuse case before a jury and are trying to persuade him to settle it quickly.A royal source claimed senior royals were shocked at his decision to have a jury trial and fear it could make things worse.They told The Sun: After the car crash of Newsnight no-one thinks a seven-hour deposition is a good idea - he were to appear in court it could be many times worse and senior royals were deeply shocked when they heard that he was demanding a jury trial.”Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkPrince Charles, Prince of WalesRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nails seen sticking out grass
story: Nails seen sticking out of grass in garden used by children - with sinister noteResidents in Swinton are concerned for the safety of children who often walk through the communal garden, directly across from the popular local Moorside Park, to get to schoolResidents in Swinton have contacted the police after they spotted metal nails in a communal garden Image: MENByKatie L WilsonSeamus McDonnellJosie Le Vay:,  Jan |commentsDisgusted residents in Swinton have contacted the police after someone left metal nails sticking up from the ground in a grassy area used by children to walk to school. One resident, who asked to remain anonymous, said she spotted the nails for the first time on January  in a communal garden, directly across from the popular local Moorside Park. The mystery stranger who left the nails also appeared to have also planted a sign nearby which reads: If you ride on the grass you may fall into a trap!! Beware!One resident who lives nearby with her daughter, told Manchester Evening News : Itaposs a  inch full-on metal nail sticking out of the ground. Itaposs horrible.My little girl loves to run around near there. All it takes is a kid to run through and trip and they could die from something like that.  She added: Thereaposs a few ways you can walk to the local schools with kids and thataposs one. Itaposs directly across from Moorside Park. That area is well used by residents even though itaposs a communal area. Sian Grant, executive director of operations at Salix Homes, said: “We can confirm that we received reports about this matter from a concerned member of the public. As soon as this was brought to our attention, we took immediate action and our Environmental Team have been on site today to investigate, however the nails had already been removed before we got there. “We will now be working closely with the police and the community to investigate the matter further and identy the culprits. “The safety of our communities is a priority for Salix Homes, and we would urge anyone with concerns about anti-social behaviour in their neighbourhoods to contact us. We’d also ask anyone with any further information about this incident to contact us on   .” Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. figures show a district in Northern Ireland has the biggest week-on-week rise in cases in the UK.More than half of local areas around the country have seen a week-on-week rise in Covid cases as Plan B restrictions come to an end. Of the  local areas in the UK,  - % - have seen a week-on-week rise in rates. The biggest was seen in Lisburn  Castlereagh, where cases went up from ,. to ,.. This was followed by Armagh City, Banbridge  Craigavon where cases increased from ,. to ,.. The top five areas with the biggest week-on-week rises are below.  Newry, Mourne  Down in Northern Ireland continues to have the highest rate in the UK, with , new cases in the seven days to January . This is the equivalent of ,. per , people, and up from a rate of ,. for the seven days to January . Armagh City, Banbridge  Craigavon in Northern Ireland has the second highest rate, up from ,. to ,., with , new cases. title: primark shopper 20 upskirting horror
story: Primark shopper, , in upskirting horror as disgusting man films her in queueThe woman was with her younger sister in Primark in Hull when a fellow shopper pointed out that a man had been videoing up her skirt. He had recorded six videos of herKevin Syder admitted the charge Image: Hull liveByKelly-Ann MillsNews ReporterMark Naylor:,  Jan  A pervert brazenly filmed up a young womanaposs skirt as she stood in the queue to pay in Primark in what the court heard was crude, ugly, perverse, disgusting opportunist behaviour.The shocked -year-old was alerted to the degrading and embarrassing violation of her privacy by another shopper. She told Hull Crown Court the disgraceful and disrespectful filming had left long-lasting effects on her and it was one of the worst days of her le.Kevin Syder admitted recording images under the womanaposs clothes on March , , Hull Live reports.Richard Butters, prosecuting, said -year-old Syder from Hull was detained by security staff at the townaposs Primark in Princes Quay, after being alerted by a member of the public. The witness spotted him using a phone to take photographs up the skirt of a woman standing in front of him in the queue.  The shopper told the woman: Excuse me, I have just seen this man taking a photograph up your skirt. The woman was with her younger sister at the time. There were six videos showing the womanaposs bottom and underwear that had been filmed by Syder. He attempted to run out of the store but he was fortunately detained very quickly by security staff, said Mr Butters. He was arrested and his phone was seized. It has had a very long lasting, profound impact on his victim. The woman later said she felt myself freeze. I felt shocked. It was extremely upsetting and shocking and I was crying, she added. I donapost even recall what I was saying. I was so shocked about what had happened. I canapost remember exactly what I was shouting. I should be able to wear whatever I wish to and not have anybody taking a photographic image up my skirt. She told the court she felt violated, adding: I feel really numb and upset. The woman said that she would have to carry the incident around with her and she would be on edge the next time she went into town, especially to Primark. This crime has left long-lasting effects on myself and my family. I think about what happened to me every day, she said. Itaposs not just the physical act of what happened but the emotional trauma from a day that stays with you. I went through one of the worst things to happen. Itaposs degrading and embarrassing. I find myself reminded of what happened. I threw away any skirt or dress that came even slightly above the knee because I genuinely felt I didnapost have the confidence to wear them. I could barely concentrate on the work I had to do. That day was one of the worst days of my le. Julia Baggs, mitigating, said Syder wanted to apologise to the victim. This was clearly an impulsive and opportunist act, said Miss Baggs. This behaviour was completely irrational. He didnapost stop and think about the impact on the complainant. He does understand the seriousness of the offence and the damage that he has caused. He is deeply remorseful and sorry for his actions. He does feel deep shame and regret and this disgraceful and disrespectful act, to use his words. He is deeply sorry for this degrading and disgraceful piece of behaviour. Syder had no previous convictions and had worked as a plasterer before becoming a long-distance lorry driver for  years, a job which he lost because of this offence. He had served in the Territorial Army for more than  years, the court heard. He had been married but has no children. Judge Michael Fanning told Syder: Itaposs upskirting. Itaposs a crude, ugly word and it describes crude, ugly, perverse, disgusting conduct. I am well aware that the impact on victims is very, very real. He told him the woman was entitled to wear her own choice of clothes and to expect that some pervert is not going to stick a camera under her skirt for his own sexual gratication. She should not have to feel degraded, humiliated and violated, said Judge Fanning. This was very much targeted offending. You saw an opportunity. You saw and seized that opportunity. You recorded that victim under her clothing and that was for your sexual gratication. The real risk was that you shared it. Fortunately, you were caught on the day, the video was seized and that brings it to an end. Syder was given an -week suspended prison sentence, with rehabilitation work, and he was ordered to pay £ compensation to the woman. He must register as a sex offender for seven years and the phone will be forfeited and destroyed. news uk-news prince-andrew-being-left-royal-"Prince Andrew ‘demands jury trial’ in civil sex caseByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan  Most royal celebrations see members of the Firm appear on the Buckingham Palace balcony to greet the crowds. So it’s likely the family will gather on the balcony to wave to royal fans in June during the Queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.However, one member of the family who won’t be making a balcony appearance is Prince Andrew.Earlier this month, a statement from Buckingham Palace confirmed the Duke of York would no longer be taking part in any public duties.It comes as he faces a civil trial in New York following sex abuse allegations made against him. He vehemently denies the claims.  However, it won’t be the first time that Andrew has not been present during a royal balcony appearance. In , the Queen was celebrating her Diamond Jubilee of  years on the throne - and an appearance by the royals on the Buckingham Palace balcony was planned.It was reported that Charles had a hand in the decision for only senior royals, such as the Duchess of Cornwall, Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge, to appear on the balcony - leaving Andrew dismayed.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Royal expert Richard Kay wrote in the Daily Mail in : For Andrew, according to one close figure, being excluded from the balcony scene was a sudden and totally unexpected demotion from front-rank to peripheral royal. It was ‘like a dagger to his heart and he hasn’t got over it’.But this was a dramatic statement of intent by Charles, who long ago decided that when he is king the Royal Family would be ‘slimmed down’. But as a friend of the Duke of York says: ‘The speed and suddenness with which Charles has acted has taken Andrew’s breath away. It’s dreadfully high-handed.’ As heir to the throne, Charles has spent his entire le preparing for the day he takes to the throne to become King. And it’s long been reported that he plans for a slimmed-down monarchy with a team of seven senior royals - that doesn’t include Prince Andrew or his daughtersapos Beatrice and Eugenie. Meanwhile, it has been reported today senior royals led by Charles and Prince William are aposshockedapos Andrew wants to fight his civil sex abuse case before a jury and are trying to persuade him to settle it quickly.The Duke of York has always denied accusations of rape and sexual assault made by his accuser Virginia Giuffre, who was this month handed the right to take the Queen’s son to trial in the United States. In his first official response to the court regarding claims made against him last August, the Queen’s son issued  straight denials of Ms Gufre’s allegations.  A royal source toldThe Sun:After the car crash of Newsnight no-one thinks a seven-hour deposition is a good idea - he were to appear in court it could be many times worse and senior royals were deeply shocked when they heard that he was demanding a jury trial.The best outcome for everyone is that this is settled as soon as possible. There are deep, deep worries that this will get worse and worse for the family and will overshadow Platinum Jubilee celebrations. title: prince andrew told palace cops
story: Prince Andrew told Palace cops this is my house...f*** off after causing security scareA tracksuit-clad Prince Andrew was said to be looking scruffy and caused Buckingham Palace Royal Protection officers to race to the Queens bedroom after being spotted outside, former officer Paul Page claimsPrince Andew at Buckingham Palace Image: Getty ImagesByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan Prince Andrew caused a security scare at Buckingham Palace before swearing at Royal Protection Officers and insisting This is my house, it has been claimed. Former royal protection officer Paul Page said the Queen aposs second son was scruffy and wearing a tracksuit when he was spotted outside the Queenaposs bedroom and he was thought to have been an intruder.He claims the Prince then threw a tantrum and swore at the officers who were trying to protect the palace. Mr Page said he was in a control room checking CCTV when they spotted a man walking alone along the Queenaposs corridor, so he went along with a sergeant and two others officers to investigate.Her Majesty was not at Buckingham Palace at the time, so this was a major potential security scare. We approached from either end of the corridor so we could surround the potential intruder, he told The Sun.He added that they soon realised it was a scruffy looking Prince Andrew wearing a tracksuit. I apologised and said, aposIaposm sorry, your Highness, we went to investigate a possible intruder in Her Majestyaposs apartmentsapos. Andrew replies, aposThis is my house, I go where I want, now f*** offapos. Mr Page, who has spoken out about his time as a royal protection officer before added that he thought Prince Andrew was a bully. I never had any problems with any other members of the Royal Family in my time at Buckingham Palace. The Queen is a lovely lady, but Prince Andrew had this nasty side to him, he treated staff terribly, he said. Speaking to the Mirror, Mr Page, who worked in the Royal Protection Command from  until , alleges he personally made three separate complaints to palace officials about the prince. He claims he is aware of “at least a dozen” other reports made by colleagues. Mr Page, whose revelations this week sparked a string of complaints about the prince, said: “Buckingham Palace launched a bullying investigation against Meghan last year after she was accused of wrongdoing. “If it’s a fair organisation that looks after its staff, an investigation should be started to confirm whether or not Andrew is guilty of being a bully and of intimidating staff.”  He alleges complaints he raised during his service were ignored because senior courtiers did not want to create a stir. Mr Page told the Sunday Mirror: “The Palace have a problem because there are instances and evidence of Prince Andrew being overbearing and verbally abusive.” In  Mr Page lost his job after he was jailed following a £ million property scam. He set up a sham company, tricking colleagues, friends and family into parting with their cash, savings and pension payouts. The judge said the scheme was “breathtakingly dishonest, relentless and callous”.  The former Buckingham Palace royal protection officer ed to public eye when he appeared in the ITV documentary, Ghislaine, Prince Andrew and the Paedophile, during which he described the access Ghislaine Maxwell had to the palace.He told the documentary Andrew would “shout and scream”his collection of toy bears on his bed were not placed in exact positions by maids. That prompted the prince’s former maid Charlotte Briggs, , to come forward with allegations. She accused Andrew, then in his s, of foul-mouthed rants and ludicrous demands. They included making her run up four flights of stairs to close his curtains while, she says, he was right next to them. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. She also told of being in tears and of hiding to avoid the “bad-tempered” and “entitled” royal. Diplomat Simon Wilson, who hosted the duke in Bahrain, previously claimed the “rude” and “boorish” prince had “childish obsessions” and was nicknamed HBH by staff – for His Buffoon Highness. Former maid Janette McGowan, , claimed she had to check a Polaroid of  teddy bears on Andrew’s bed and lay them out in exact positions to avoid him becoming angry. Mr Page claimed there “must have been at least a dozen complaints” about bullying in the time he was there.  He alleged: “It was well known in the palace, but no investigation was conducted by the royal household.” Mr Page claimed a colleague had been called a “fat lardy-a***d c***” by the prince after stopping a woman at the gates who had not been listed as an invited guest. He said: “Even the woman went bright red and said, ‘I’m really sorry’. Another time a woman got locked in and he came down f-ing and blinding and ranting.” Andrew,  – ninth in line to the throne – is facing calls to be evicted from -room Royal Lodge after being told to stop using his HRH title and stripped of his military titles and charitable affiliations. He is fighting sex assault claims in the US in a civil suit by Virginia Giuffre, the alleged sex slave of his former pal Jeffrey Epstein. He vehemently denies the claims. news uk-news prince-charles-terried-becoming-king-"Prince Charles reveals how hes limiting carbon footprintByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsPrince Charles is “dreading” the moment he becomes King and takes over from the Queen, a royal expert has said. Charles has been heir to the throne for much of his le and has constantly been preparing for the day he finally becomes monarch.However, he will only become King once his beloved mother the Queen sadly passes away. And according to royal biographer Penny Junor, it will be a terrying prospect for the Prince of Wales. Speaking on Podcast Royal, she said: “This is a moment that he has been dreading all his le really because his achieving the top job, the job he’s been training for and preparing for all these years does inevitably mean the death of his mother and he loves his mother very dearly.  “So it’s going to be a very vicious week, moment and I think that I am sure that he is pretty terried of the whole prospect. He is a very emotional man and a sensitive man, he did take the death of his father very badly. He takes the death of any loved one to heart and I think it would be, it’s devastating for him as it is for anyone who loses a much-loved mother.” Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Charles was born in , just a few years before his mother became Queen in . Since being invested as the Prince of Wales by his mum in July  heaposs worked to support her and carve his own path within the royal family as heir to the throne. With the support of his we Camilla, Charles has taken on more responsibility within The Firm as the Queen begins to slow down, as she turns  this year. Heaposs also taken the lead on several family matters and assisted the Queen to decide on the logistics of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry stepping down from their senior roles in .Charlesapos plans for a slimmed down monarchy when he takes the throne are well known, and heaposs reportedly looking to have a team of seven senior royals.  Royal author Angela Levin told talkRADIO : Prince Charles has wanted for a very long time to cut the monarchy down to save costs and to make people be worth the money that they got from the taxpayer.I think the outer edge of the family, which the Queen has wanted to keep together for a very long time for sentimental reasons, which at her age she didnapost really particularly want change which I think is understandable. But he wants to change and I think he will do that. news uk-news queen-launches-pricey-brand-posh-"The Queen arrives at her Sandringham residenceByJo RileySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan |comments The Queen has launched her own brand of posh tomato ketchup and brown sauce - but the products have a royal price tag hanging around the bottle neck.Her Majesty, , has put The Queenaposs Tomato Sauce, which is aposideal for breakfast or any time of the dayapos, on sale at her Sandringham estate in Norfolk. But each bottle will set you back an eye-watering £ - compared to Sainsburyaposs own brand, which sets you back just p. The sauce, which is flavoured with dates, apple juice and spices, comes in a glass jar with a Royal Estate label. It states on the bottle: A real family favourite, packed full of tomato and lightly spiced, this ketchup is delightful. Vibrant and fruity, this ketchup can be enjoyed any time of the day, perfect to add flavour to a dish.  The Queen is also selling a brown sauce for the same price, with the description: a tomato based sauced packed with vinegar and spices. The Monarch is said to be a fan of the sauces but doesnapost use the condiments on a regular basis. The Queenaposs former chef Darren McGrady said in  that kitchen staff would make their own versions of takeaway favourites for the royal family. However, they never eat fast food - so you wonapost catch royal hands around a Big Mac any time soon. He explained: It always tickled me at Balmoral, we would make our own burgers. They would shoot deer, and we would do venison burgers. Thereaposd be gorgeous cranberry and everything stuffed into them, but we never set buns out. He went on to say: Her Majestyaposs Victorian upbringing dictates that the only thing you would pick up and eat with your fingers is afternoon tea. They would have burgers, but not the buns. So they would eat it with their kne and fork. Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. He also said HM hates pizza and during his time in her service, not a single one was ever served. But she doesnapost tell anyone what her favourite food is - and for a very good reason. The Queen has attended banquets around the world and tried a number of dferent cuisines, but when it comes to her favourite food, sheaposs been keeping the exact dish under wraps for years. But a royal insider has explained how she doesnapost ulge her favourite food before travelling, so that she isnapost served the same thing everywhere she goes. title: ridiculous food prices costing hard
story: Ridiculous food prices are costing hard-working people an arm and a legIn this weeks column Val, the mum of Mirror columnist and football legend Robbie Savage, gets her knickers in a twist at the price of a roast dinner, and wants to bobsleigh at the Beijing Winter OlympicsFood prices are on the rise Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesopinionByVal Savage:,  Jan |comments A man called Clive paid £ for a leg of lamb from Tesco and his we’s rage went viral, as the cool young people say on Instagram. She was so incensed she had to later send out a message confirming ‘Clive is alive’.I’m not surprised she was furious. THIRTY POUNDS  I’d want a whole sheep and a field of turnips for that. Now I love a roast dinner more than most. Just thinking about tender meat soaking up gravy makes me drool. But come on, prices are getting ridiculous.I was going to wax lyrical about how mutton can taste just as delicious, and how scrag ends of meat in a stew contains the same goodness. I was tempted to suggest putting lesser cuts of meat in a big pie to make a substantial meal for half the price.  But then I stopped myself and thought: why, decades after our parents had rations, are we having to think this way  Why are we putting up with outrageous price rises on essentials  Why are honest, hardworking people punished in the pocket and at the dinner table  My dad always said, whenever the budget announcements were made, working people were hit hardest with the increased price of a pint and packet of cigarettes. Now it’s food. Thinking about it left me angrier than Clive’s we. Bittersweet time for Her Majesty Staying at Wood Farm cottage at Sandringham in the run up to the th anniversary of her father’s death next weekend will be extra emotional for the Queen as it’s the first time she’s been there without Prince Philip. I imagine it will feel comforting one moment, heartbreaking the next. The rooms, the gardens, the views and even the smells will remind her of the good times she’s had there, but the people she shared them with are gone. Loch Lomond is the special place where Colin and I enjoyed our special times. Each year I’d askhe’d like to have a holiday in Portugal or Loch Lomond, and he always chose Scotland. We loved everything about our trips there, from the long drive with our Motown music, Scotch eggs and tin of travel sweets. We’d always stop at Tebay services which has beautul scenery, turkey pie to die for and a farm shop.  We stayed in a cosy lodge, where even a cup of tea or a Chinese takeaway seemed to taste nicer. We’d walk in the wilderness for miles, spotting red deer, and we’d end up at little tea shops where it would have been rude not to order cake. Sometimes we’d drive to explore the surrounding areas and we’d get lost, in the days before sat nav, but somehow always found a warm, friendly pub. Colin loved the gentle pace and peace of our holidays there. And I adored how everything about the place made us both feel so relaxed and happy. I get a little tearful when Loch Lomond appears on television. Then I remind myself I was lucky to have had such fantastic times there.  Bloominapos solo birthday While Boris had a party for his birthday, I spent mine alone. My two sons bought me flowers and left them at the end of the drive because we wouldn’t have dreamt of breaking the social distance laws. I am too tired to be angry. Listening to all the political rows has left me weary and drained. Instead, I just wish all sides of the political spectrum would get their heads together and get our country up and running again.  Drama a real blast It can be hard to stay awake in January when it’s a long, grey, damp anticlimax. But an explosion scene in the new TV series Trigger Point made me jump out of my skin. My eyes popped so wide I felt more awake than I had in weeks.  Loo are you talking to  Fancy new research says lots of British phrases are no longer used because the younger generation are baffled by them. What a load of codswallop. Whoever did the survey needs to listen to my daily chat with my friend Beryl because we use such phrases constantly. I say this as a woman who still calls those sweets Opal Fruits and will never say Starburst. So here’s my guide to those sayings which have got young people’s knickers in a twist. Flogging a dead horse means there’s no point in arguing any more - that’s what I say whenever I’m giving our Robert a talking-to because he never he pays any notice. I’m fit for the knacker’s yard means every bit of me is falling to pieces and no use to anyone, which is how I describe myself these days.  Dropping a clanger is a less posh way of saying committing a faux pas - something my friends say I do every day. No wonder no one understands that ‘spend a penny’ means going to the loo because they usually cost a pound now. And a dog’s dinner is what I create each time I try cooking. But I have no idea where ‘daft as a brush’ comes from - or why my friends use it whenever they talk about me. Bobsleigh, the coolest sport The Australian Open tennis has turned my body clock upside down because I’m glued to the coverage. Soon I’ll be riveted by the Beijing Olympic Winter Games. The bobsleigh is my favourite. Me and my friend Janet reckonwe could get in one we’d shoot down faster than anyone . But we’d laugh so hysterically there’d need to be room in my skin-tight race suit for a Tena Lady.If you’d like to write to Val, please email features@mirror or write to Val Savage, PO Box , E DD The Mirror makes a donation to the Alzheimer’s Society in lieu of payment. alzheimersRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Novak DjokovicPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRobbie SavageAustralian OpenWinter Olympic GamesRoyal FamilyMental healthPrice risesAlzheimers diseaseBobsledDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: school bans year 11 pupils
story: School bans Year  pupils from loo breaks during lessons in zero-tolerance approachUlidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy where the loos operate as a one-in one-out policy at break and lunchtimes -pupils want to use the loo during lessons they need to have a medical card or exemptionUlidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy Image: Ulidia Integrated CollegeByLauren HarteAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A secondary school bans Year  pupils from going to the loo during lessons over Covid- breaches and vandalism. Ulidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy where the loos operate as a one-in one-out policy at break and lunchtimes.Requests to use the loo during class time will be refused unless the pupil shows a medical card or exemption to the teacher, parents were informed via email.Furthermore, pupils who need to use the toilet outside the specied times during their period will need a note from their parents, which will then be dated and counter-signed by their form teacher, BelfastLive reports.  The school said it has been dealing with ious issues amongst an increasing number of Year  pupils, which included disrespecting staff, misuse of toilets, unorm breaches, Covid- breaches, and vandalism. The school has said that from January  it was implementing a zero-tolerance approach.One parent Ciaran McCauley told BBC Radio Ulsteraposs Evening Extra on Thursday: My son is in Year  at the school and he came home on Friday last and was quite concerned because he had become aware of the email that had gone out to the parents of Year  students.It doesnapost affect my son directly but he was able to empathise with the issues that might be impacting the other students.  He complained that the toilets were being locked and students and parents had been asked to supply notes. If the children needed to access toiletsthey were on their period, they had to bring a note in, have it counter-signed by a teacher and dated. Ciaran believes itaposs an unfair policy and wrong. He added: I thought it was regressive and led to embarrassing situations for kids. Unfortunately, we live in a society where periods still have a stigma attached to them and theyaposre still an embarrassment for many.  Ciaran initially thought the email was a rumour, but when he contacted the school they confirmed it. In a statement, principal Michael Houston said: As a rights respecting school, Ulidia Integrated College is in full support of the Period Dignity Project, which refers to the accessibility and availability of essential care needed to support a period in conjunction with the removal and breaking of stigma and taboo around periods. Education is a key factor in breaking the stigma surrounding periods and promoting respect, understanding and open discussions about what people may experience. Following repeated incidents of vandalism and breaches of Covid- safeguards in the toilets, many of which occurred during lesson times, some facilities had to be closed, replaced or repaired. We want to ensure that all pupils in the particular year group affected are always given access to clean and sanitary facilities during their period. Mr Houston added that the measures are temporary and protective, only relevant for the pupils in a single year group who have to leave during lessons as facilities are freely available before school, at break and lunch time, end of day and between lessons as required. He added: In addition all single person all access toilets are open too all pupils all day every day without exception. It comes two months after a Co Down grammar school was criticised for its toilet policy after it emerged there were just three toilets for , pupils.The rules about going to the toilet imposed at Glenlola Collegiate School in Bangor were labelled “draconian”.Thehas contacted the school for a comment. title: stunning mansion house pool secret
story: Stunning mansion house with pool has secret Lord of the Rings-themed gardenThe stunning Grade II listed home in St. Margarets-at-Clfe, Dover, Kent is on the market for £. million and would be a favourite with Lord of the Rings fansA six-bed house has a secret that is perfect for any JRR Tolkien fan Image: Sothebys International RealtyByAndy CrickLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Jan |commentsA six-bed house has a secret that is perfect for any JRR Tolkien fan - a Lord of the Rings-themed garden. The Grade ll Listed baronial gothic manor house oozes elegance with castle turrets on the roof and its sweeping staircase in the hall. The th century property boasts a library, outdoor swimming pool, tennis courts, a gym and cellars. The bedrooms include one with a four poster bed. But itaposs not until prospective buyers walk through the picturesque walled garden that the real treat is revealed.  A Hobbit Hole - like that inhabited by Bilbo and Froddo Baggins in the fantasy books and Hollywood blockbusters - is hidden in the woodland. The tiny, green painted shed even comes with a trademark circular door. But the magic doesnapost end there, there is also a stunning tree house - complete with lighting and a fireplace.  The elf-like wooden hut is built up in the branches and access is gained via two rope bridges. The house in St. Margarets-at-Clfe, Dover, Kent is on the market for £.million with Sothebyaposs International Realty. The Rightmove listing reads: Oxney Court is an elegant Grade ll baronial gothic manor house located on the Kent coast. It has extensive grounds and formal gardens together with further accommodation in two cottages.  It is situated in a most secluded and discrete setting, accessed by a long private drive. Oxney Court has an interesting history. Whilst there has been a house on this site for a few hundred years the current house dates from the late th century.  Substantial gates open to a driveway which passes through ancient woodland before continuing through more formal gardens on approaching the house. A striking entrance porch leads to an octagonal reception hall with stone flooring.  Moving through, the staircase hall has a stone fireplace and a sweeping staircase leading to the first floor landing. Beyond, the elegant principal reception rooms stretch across the front of the house. The main accommodation is provided over three floors. The ground floor accommodation consists of a fine, generously proportioned dining room which is in the gothic style. There is a large bow window with detailing and a high ceiling with ornate mouldings. The drawing room has a striking mirrored wall and a double sided fireplace to the end of the room which also opens into the library with fitted bookshelves.  Beyond is the triple aspect sitting room which, like the dining room, has gothic detail. Together these rooms provide a wonderful space for both family living and formal entertaining. A spacious corridor leads to a double aspect study, led with oak and on to the kitchen breakfast room. The kitchen is fitted with handmade oak units arranged around an island unit and is naturally illuminated by a large roof light.  An elegant hexagonal conservatory is set to the southern corner of the house and views of the garden to the rear. The first floor consists of elegant and spacious bedroom suites. The master bedroom is of good proportions having a bow window with easterly views and double doors to a well appointed bathroom. This can also be approached from the tower staircase. From here, double doors overlook the turreted porch below. The family bathroom is situated to the rear of the first floor. Across the front of the house are three well-appointed suites, the largest enjoying a triple aspect. A fth bedroom is found at the rear, adjacent to which is a large rooftop balcony with a southerly aspect.  There are cellars and store rooms beneath the main house. But then the Lord of the Rings surprise is revealed as it adds: The gardens and grounds are laid to areas of lawn interspersed with laurels and rhododendrons and surrounded by deep belts of trees and woodland.The lawns are underplanted with a great iety of flowering bulbs, shrubs and other plants and the more formal garden to the rear of the house has deep herbaceous borders enclosed by yew hedging and high brick walls.There is a further area of garden, mostly laid to lawn, as well as a rose garden which is enclosed by box hedging, and an arbour. In the woods there is a magnicent tree house with rope bridges and a hobbit house. news uk-news sue-gray-plans-send-report-"Sue Gray report: Met Police request ‘minimal reference’ByAbigail OLearyNews ReporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Sue Gray plans to send a cut-back version of her report to Downing Street “shortly” after y talks with the Met Police concluded, the Mirror understands. The report is expected to be sent to No in the coming hours or days after Ms Gray handed over evidence of possible lockdown breaches to Scotland Yard.No will then decide when to publish it, with the government previously suggesting this would happen when Parliament is sitting - which is next on Monday.  However, the report is set to follow the Met Police request to include only “minimal reference” to Downing Street parties the force is investigating. It is unclearor when a fuller report with all the details will be published, after the Met finishes its investigation. The politan Police asked the top civil servant to make minimal references to the parties it is investigating in her report to avoid prejudicing its inquiry. Scotland Yard is looking at a number of events in Downing Street and Whitehall during the pandemic - but the force has not specied which ones.Reports have suggested it could be as many as eight gatherings. At the same time, Sue Grayaposs report had been expected this week but the timing has been thrown into chaos by the Metaposs bombshell announcement of a police probe on Tuesday. The Whitehall inquiry is understood to be still ongoing but Ms Gray may be forced to decide whether to delay her report or strip out key details. Opposition MPs blasted the appearance of an establishment stitch-up and a Whitehall whitewash, which could buy Boris Johnson a reprieve.The Prime Minister will spend the weekend at his Chequers retreat as he seeks to shore up his battered leadership. In a statement on Friday, Scotland Yard said: For the events the Met is investigating, we asked for minimal reference to be made in the Cabinet Office report. The Met did not ask for any limitations on other events in the report, or for the report to be delayed, but we have had ongoing contact with the Cabinet Office, including on the content of the report, to avoid any prejudice to our investigation. However some legal figures questioned why publishing the Whitehall report would prejudice the police investigation. news uk-news teen-receives-message-beyond-grave-"Taylor McCormack receives thoughtful Christmas presentByAntony ThrowerArike Idris:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsA teenager has received a message from beyond the grave from her best friend who drowned in a canal. Taylor McCormack, , was devastated when Rodney Zinoro’s body was found in a Manchester canal in May . The pair had been best friends for several years and stayed in close contact when Rodney moved north from Essex.And now Taylor can hear her friend whenever she wants through a Build-a-Bear gt, complete with a voice recording, Essex Live reported.She said: “I was just shocked that someone would even do that. I was like aposOh my God, that is the most thoughtful gt anyone had ever given me. The fact that his voice is in a teddy, itaposs just so pure and I can hug it and listen to it when Iaposm sad so I think I was just happy, If Iaposm sad, I can just talk to it because itaposs got his voice. Itaposs not him, but itaposs him to me. The feeling to know that the teddy is in my room just made me feel happy. He was such a genuine person and he would literally light up a room as soon as he walked in. There was no bad energy, he was just positive vibes, and he was always thereyou needed him. He was just like the best person ever. The thoughtful gt was a Christmas present from her younger sister Maddie. Rodneyaposs body was repatriated to Zimbabwe ahead of his funeral in September . His brother filmed proceedings and sent it to Taylor so she could watch. Taylor added: I was a mess for ages, I still am to be fair. I would just think of him for a day and Iaposll just start crying as the emotions just wouldnapost stop. I just broke down, I couldnapost breathe. I [was thinking] aposThis isnapost true, he was one of the best people in the world, why has he been taken so soon apos I made myself believe that it wasnapost real. The feeling was just so heavy on your chest, itaposs like aposNo way this is real, Iaposm dreaming.apos I just couldnapost stop crying.” Footage of Taylor using the bear went viral on TikTok. title: two lesser known omicron symptoms
story: Two lesser known Omicron symptoms to be aware of as stealth iant on the riseWith infection rates of the ‘stealth’ Omicron Covid iant on the rise in the UK, we take a look at two lesser known symptoms, as well as the classic signs you should look out forDizziness is one of the lesser known symptoms of Omicron Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Jan |commentsCovid infection rates have been falling in the UK since early January, but the decline is now coming to a halt.Cases of coronavirus were soaring due to the new Omicron iant, but helped largely by the booster rollout, cases started to fall.It has also been found that Omicron causes milder infection, and hospital admissions and deaths remain relatively low – however it is highly transmissible.It’s important to be aware of Omicron symptoms to avoid the further spread of the virus, especially as UK health officials are now monitoring a new Covid- strain. Nicknamed ‘stealth Omicron’, it appears to be more contagious than the original, and is spreading faster than the original iant.What are the symptoms of Omicron  Omicron is a iant of Covid, which means the classic symptoms are a new, continuous cough, a fever and a loss of smell taste, according to the NHS.However, scientists behind the ZOE Covid symptom app have revealed people testing positive for Omicron are logging symptoms more closely associated with the common cold. The top five symptoms found in in positive cases are:Runny nose Headache FatigueSneezingSore throat However, there are two lesser known symptoms that it is important to be aware of – back pain and dizziness. Dr Ann Mary, Consultant, General Medicine, Amrita Hospital, Kochi, told IANS: “Back pain, though common in most viral fevers, but compared to Delta, Omicron patients tend to have more back pain and less loss of smell and taste. “A signicant number of these patients are having back-breaking pain in the lower back and severe myalgia which is adding to the patientaposs woes.” Brits will be well aware of the three main symptoms of coronavirus – a new, continuous cough, a fever and a loss of taste and or smell. These are the officially recognised symptoms according to the NHS. However, with the new Omicron iant, symptoms have been described as being more similar to a common cold. Itaposs important to be aware of the symptoms in order to limit the spread of Covid. most common symptoms of Omicron, overtaking the  aposclassicapos Covid symptoms Is a rash a symptom of Omicron  Is altered taste a symptom of Omicron  Warning in your eyes doctor warns could be sign of Omicron Warning signs that the Omicron symptoms youaposre experiencing arenapost mind Omicron symptoms parents may be able to spot in children  least pleasant Omicron symptom – including dizziness  The NHS also reports that dizziness can be a sign of Covid, although it’s perhaps a lesser known symptom. They describe the dizziness as a “sensation of spinning or an altered sense of motion often called vertigo” and “lightheadedness”. The NHS notes that this can occur “during the acute phase of the infection, during recovery or as part of Long Covid symptoms.” What to doyou think you have Covid If you have any of these symptoms, especially the three aposclassicapos symptoms, you should book a free PCR test, and self isolate until you have the result. You should only leave your home to get tested, but there are a select few other reasons you can leave self isolation.Lateral Flow tests should only be usedyou donapost have any symptoms.
